term.longtitle: IUPAC Gold Book - surface excess, n^σ
term.title: surface excess

item.text: For an interface, the adsorption or surface excess of a given component is defined as the difference between the amount of component actually present in the system, and that which would be present (in a reference system) if the bulk concentration in the adjoining phases were maintained up to a chosen geometrical dividing surface (Gibbs dividing surface). For a solid/liquid interface in which no component of the liquid phase penetrates into the solid, the surface excess (or adsorption) of component i is defined as: n i σ = n i- V l c i l is the total amount of i in the system, V l is the volume of an arbitrarily chosen amount of bulk liquid (in the framework of the so-called algebraic method) and cil is its bulk concentration in the liquid.

item.alttext: n i σ = n i- V l c i l
